Donald Trump's obsession with the Nobel Peace Prize
subhead: Nominated by several leaders, such as Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, Trump dreams about the prestigious prize, as he hopes to secure a ceasefire in Ukraine at his meeting with Vladimir Putin in Alaska.

Ahead of the Trump-Putin summit in Alaska, Ukrainians have become bitter
subhead: Donald Trump's threats against Vladimir Putin are no longer taken seriously in Ukraine, and Volodymyr Zelensky's absence from the August 15 meeting has come as a shock. Many in Kyiv are convinced that Russia will never give up on taking control of the entire country.

headline: Deployment of 800 National Guard troops in DC begins
subhead: The move, announced on Thursday by the Pentagon, is part of a federal takeover of law enforcement by President Donald Trump, despite falling violent crime rates in the US capital.

headline: In Lyon, green islands offer a cooling solution to heatwaves
subhead: Elected officials and urban planners say greening the city must shift from a landscaping approach to a strategy focused on cooling in order to adapt to climate change – as was done in the former industrial district of Gerland.

headline: Charlotte Perriand's family's relentless mission to keep her legacy alive
subhead: Since the death of architect and designer Charlotte Perriand in 1999, her legacy has been in the devoted hands of her daughter and son-in-law. Their meticulous work has played a significant role in elevating the prolific 'Charlotte' to the rank of design icon.

Senegalese sailors on French fishing boats: 'They have the maritime spirit in their blood'
subhead: Over the past decade in Brittany, western France, fishing boat owners have been hiring crew members from Senegal, who are drawn to the region by wages higher than those paid in Spain.

headline: Who's going to lie down on the couch? 'The Sopranos,' the first TV series to tackle mental health
subhead: 'Breaking The Script' (3/5). In 1999, the TV series 'The Sopranos' introduced viewers to a mafia boss suffering from depression. Through the intense exchanges between this anti-hero and his therapist, mental health became a central theme on television for the first time, where it has continued to thrive ever since.

headline: 'Who shot JR?': The 'Dallas' episode that had the whole world on edge
subhead: 'Breaking The Script' (1/6). These legendary TV episodes shaped and transformed the genre. In 1980, at the end of the third season of 'Dallas,' the infamous JR Ewing was gunned down outside his office door. For eight long months, suspense over the shooter's identity kept viewers hooked. Spoiler alert!
